history.content:
There is Field Studies and different tutoring opportunities through the Student Learning Center slc.berkeley.edu no CS, but there is math, stats, english, etc.

Different clubs (CSUA, HKN, IEEE, UPE) all offer tutoring, so if you're in any of those you could do that. 

Maybe checking in with the courses this semester and see if they need more lab assistants?

Applying to be a academic intern (you probably wouldn't get units) for a decal you previously took/have the skills to help with.

There are different tutoring programs that do outreach to local highschools and middle schools.

PIE comes to mind, there are other. Even reaching out to local highschools or berkeley community college to volunteer.

The academic units (student housing) hire tutors. They might still be hiring!

If you really wanna teach, and are willing to put in the time to search for opportunities, I think you'll find something!

children.subject:
^ PiE decal is a great way to do some teaching! (And I'm definitely not biased by being on the team running it)  You get to mentor a high school robotics team, which imo is a pretty cool opportunity.  We're always looking for more mentors, so if you're interested, feel free to come to our first class meeting, which is Monday in 220 Jacobs or Thursday in 210 Jacobs from 6:30 to 8:30 (they're both the same lesson, so you only need to go to one).  If you want more information, you should check out our website.  You can also come to the first day of class decide whether or not you want to participate based on that.

If you're more interested in teaching college students, you can probably still get a position as an academic intern / lab assistant for a class you've taken previously.  The official applications have probably all closed by now, but if you email the course staff, they'll most likely still have space open.  At the very least, there's no harm in asking.
CS 88 (https://cs88-website.github.io/) is still hiring for Lab Assistants! Please email me (andrewtan@berkeley.edu) if you're interested.

history.content: I know CSM and course staff are pretty much done taking applicants, but does anyone know other ways to get involved in teaching on campus at this point?
history.subject: opportunities to teach/help out with courses this semester?
